title: 109_hr3492
content: The "Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005" prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act now prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts, except for actions directly related to the account. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits creditors from using adverse information to raise interest rates on credit card accounts, except for account-related actions. The use of adverse information must be clearly disclosed to consumers by the credit card issuer. SEC. 3. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and percentage of the outstanding balance, along with the estimated number of months to pay off the balance. The Truth in Lending Act now includes requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. Consumers must pay the required minimum monthly payments and refrain from making further advances or extensions of credit to maintain the balance. The creditor must apply the applicable annual percentage rate of interest in effect at the time of disclosure. The creditor must disclose the date and applicable annual percentage rate of interest, considering different rates for various outstanding balances. If an introductory rate is in effect, the creditor must apply the temporary rate that will change based on an index or formula for future adjustments. The creditor must disclose the annual percentage rate of interest for the introductory or temporary period and for the remainder of the amortization period, based on an index or formula. SEC. 4. ADVANCED NOTICE REQUIRED BEFORE INCREASING RATES OR FEES ON CREDIT CARD ACCOUNTS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts. The notice must be provided at least 30 days before the change takes effect. The Truth in Lending Act now requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates on credit card accounts. The notice must be given at least 30 days before the change, except for changes due to a change in another indexed rate. In such cases, the notice must be given 60 days in advance. The creditor may apply the new rate to any outstanding balance as of the notice date. The Truth in Lending Act requires advance notice of any increase in fees on credit card accounts. No fees can be imposed before the end of a 30-day period from the date the obligor receives a specific notice. Notices must be mailed separately to the obligor without any advertising or disclosures. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of fee increases on credit card accounts. Fees cannot be imposed before a 30-day period from when the obligor receives a notice. The notice must explain how, when, and why a fee will be imposed, along with options for addressing it.
